LOAN AND PROJECT SUMMARY 

People’s Republic of Bangladesh  
 
Targeting Classification: General  intervention

The Project is classified as category B. Initial environmental examinations 
(IEEs) for the Project have been completed. The summary IEE is in 
Appendix 15.  
 
The Project has four components: (i) construction of 353 kilometers (km) 
of  gas  transmission  pipelines  for  transporting  360  million  cubic  feet  per 
day (MMCFD) of natural gas to expand the gas supply network to the less 
developed region of the country, (ii) field appraisal and survey of an area 
of  about  1,250  km2  encompassing  five  gas  fields  to  delineate  available 
reserves,  (iii)  200  km  gas  distribution  network  in  Rajshahi  area,  and  (iv) 
support for building the capacity of gas sector agencies.  
 
The relatively low utilization of natural gas in Bangladesh has constrained 
the  commercial,  industrial,  and  rural  development  of  the  country.  The 
country’s  gas  infrastructure  is  in  poor  condition  due  to  a  lack  of 
commercial  orientation  and  inadequate  funding  for  maintenance  and 
expansion.  The  Government’s  poverty  reduction  strategy  emphasizes 
implementation of policies directed toward expanding the national gas grid 
to  cover  less  developed  regions  of  the  country,  and  to  promote 
industrialization and accelerate balanced regional development that would 
help reduce widespread poverty. In this regard, further development of the 
main  natural  energy  resource  in  Bangladesh  to  meet  the  increasing 
demand for primary commercial energy is vital. Natural gas provides 90% 
of  fuel  for  power  generation.  It  is  a  clean  source  of  energy  bringing 
significant  environmental  and  social  benefits  through  reduced  ambient 
and indoor air pollution. 
 
Petrobangla  has  formulated  an  investment  plan  for  oil,  gas,  and  mineral 
resources  for  the  period  2002–2020  that  envisages  investments  of  $3 
billion  for  the  gas  sector  including  exploration,  field  development, 
transmission, and distribution. The investment plan, which is based on a 
study  financed  by  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB),  includes  several 
projects  likely  to  be  taken  up  by  the  private  sector.  To  support  the 
investment  plan,  the  Government  developed  a  gas  sector  reform  road 
map (GSRR), which will be implemented over 5 years. The GSRR covers 
(i)  institutional  and  financial  restructuring  of  gas  sector  companies  to 
ensure  long-term financial  sustainability; (ii) strengthening  public–private 
partnership in the gas sector aimed at creating an environment for private 
sector-led  growth;  (iii)  transformation  of  gas  companies  to  diversify 
ownership  involving  private  investors;  (iv)  restructuring  and  unbundling 
gas  sector  institutions  and  enterprises;  and (v) market-oriented  energy

Poverty analysis was undertaken during project preparation. The Project’s 
poverty reduction impacts will be significant, particularly in less developed 
regions. Income levels are likely to increase due to new opportunities that 
are  expected  to  be  opened  up,  and  the  increase  in  employment 
opportunities  from  industrial  development and  other activities  related to 
economic diversification. 
 
The Project will create about 3,000 person-months of job opportunities for 
unskilled  labor  and  will  increase  access  to  cleaner  fuel  for  power 
generation,  transport,  and  household  use.  Air  quality  improvement  in 
urban centers and indoors will be substantial. 
 
The  Project  is  financially  sound  and  economically  viable,  with  a  financial 
rate  of  return  of  12%  and  a  minimum  economic  internal  rate  of  return  of 
28.1%. Sensitivity analysis indicates that the Project remains viable under 
adverse conditions.

Natural Gas Resources

23. 
The low utilization of natural gas in Bangladesh has constrained commercial, industrial, 
and rural development. To improve the situation, several major initiatives are being taken in the 
gas sector. Petrobangla’s investment plan for oil, gas, and mineral resources for 2002–2020 is 
one initiative. Another is the implementation of the GSRR. The GSRR covers (i) institutional and 
financial  restructuring  of  gas  sector  companies  to  ensure  long-term  financial  sustainability,  (ii) 
restructuring  of  gas  sector  entities,  (iii)  strengthening  of  public–private  participation  aimed  at 
creating an environment for private sector-led growth, (iv) diversification of the ownership of gas 
sector  companies,  (v)  market-oriented  energy  pricing,  and  (vii)  promotion  of  sectoral  e-
governance. The GSRR will be implemented in conjunction with the Project.

The  Government’s  poverty  reduction  strategy  emphasizes  implementation  of  policies 
directed toward expanding the natural gas grid to cover less developed areas, particularly in the 
western region of the country. The strategy will also accelerate balanced regional development

indigenous  energy  resource  in  Bangladesh  to  meet  the  increasing  demand  for  primary 
commercial  energy.  It  will  increase  the  pace  of  economic  development  in  less  developed 
regions  of  the  country  by  expanding  the  sustainable  supply  and  use  of  natural  gas  to  replace 
polluting  fossil  and  biomass  fuels.  Use  of  natural  gas  will  also  improve  indoor  and  outdoor  air 
quality and reduce respiratory diseases.

Technical Aspects 

43. 
The  total  present  gas  demand  in  the  country  is  about  1,350  MMCFD.  Government 
estimates show that this will increase to 2,420 MMCFD in 2015 and 3,785 MMCFD in 2025. If 
this trend persists, Bangladesh will require 105 MMCFD in 2018 and 4.47 TCF additional gas by 
2025  from  new  discoveries  to  meet  its  commercial  energy  demand.  All  technical  exploratory 
studies indicate that Bangladesh has adequate gas reserves to meet its requirements.  
 
44. 
Network  analysis  demonstrates  the  constraints  in  the  existing  gas  supply  system.  The 
least-cost  analysis  shows  that  overcoming  those  constraints  will  involve  installation  of 
compressors at selected transmission points, and looping, depending on the growth in demand. 
The  existing  network  will  not  be  able  to  meet  the  demand  level  beyond  2007,  when  the  peak 
demand would be 1,796 MMCFD. To address these constraints, the NSSE involves installation 
of  compression  facilities  at  Muchai  and  Ashuganj  South.  These  together  with  the  recently 
commissioned Rashidpur-Habiganj loop will augment the throughput of 1,564 MMCFD in 2009. 
Additional compressor facility at Ashuganj west will have to be installed to maintain the supply to 
the major consumption centers in the eastern regions. An additional loop line and compressor at 
Elenga  will  be  installed  to  allow  an  adequate  supply  to  the  western  region,  with  or  without 
extensions  to  Bheramara,  Rajshahi,  and  Khulna.  Such  improvements  will  enable  the  present 
project design to serve for the natural gas system for the next 25 years or more.
